thread.title: X Factor's Yes Lad gear up to release first single: 'We want to bring a bit of fun to the charts'
thread.title_full: X Factor's Yes Lad gear up to release first single: 'We want to bring a bit of fun to the charts'

author: alistair foster
title: X Factor's Yes Lad gear up to release first single: 'We want to bring a bit of fun to the charts'
text:
Rashford can be an England legend if he gets club time, writes Murphy 
A boy band put together by the mastermind behind Take That say they want to put the fun back into music, after criticising the charts for being too “doom and gloom”. 
Yes Lad, five singers from the North-West, have been put together by Nigel Martin-Smith, who believes they can be as big as Gary Barlow and his bandmates. 
They already have a dedicated fanbase, with many camping outside Martin-Smith’s office for a glimpse of the boys — Cian Gleeson, 20, Joel Healey, 19, Sonny Hardman, 20, from Manchester, Lewis Maxwell, 17, from Liverpool, and Jake Donlan, 20. 
Maxwell said: “All our lives have changed dramatically. We are all working-class lads and were all in college or working — places like Subway, Tesco, the Co-op. (©Thames / Syco ) 
Then this guy came along and said, ‘I’m going to make you massive!’ It’s all a bit of a dream. He had so much success before we were even born. He’s done it all before. We see Nigel more than our parents.” 
Hardman added: “We want to bring a bit of fun to the charts because it’s all a bit doom and gloom at the moment. Songs about people’s dead dogs, and stuff like that. X Factor winner Matt Terry - in pictures X Factor winner Matt Terry - in pictures 1/5 Shock 
Matt Terry falls to the floor as he discovers he's won the X Factor Syco/Thames/Dymond 
Saara Aalto and her mentor Sharon Osbourne, and Matt Terry with his menotor Syco/Thames/Dymond 
Matt Terry's first reaction to winning the series ITV 
Terry's mentor Nicole Scherzinger told him he "tore the roof off" with his performances Syco/Thames/Dymond 
Matt Terry and Saara Aalto perform with Kylie Minogue in the X Factor final Syco/Thames/Dymond 
"As well as singing, we can dance too, so we can bring a lot of fun to the stage.” Healey believes there “is a massive gap in the industry for a boy band like us” and added: “ We don’t take ourselves too seriously. 
"A lot of people in the charts are taking themselves too seriously and we’re like, ‘Let’s just write pop songs and make people happy!’” 
A slightly different line-up of the band appeared on last year’s X Factor but were eliminated before the live finals. Read more
